head.title: Shuttle Is Warmed Up for a 9-Day Mission

hedline.hl1: Shuttle Is Warmed Up for a 9-Day Mission

block.p: NASA engineers worked today to keep unusually cold Florida weather from delaying the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour early Thursday.

NASA engineers worked today to keep unusually cold Florida weather from delaying the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour early Thursday.

To keep the shuttle warm, ground workers blew warm air inside and pumped warm nitrogen over the devices that steer the shuttle's boosters, said John Stealey said, a test director at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

In addition, an automatic system of warming bands was wrapped around the O-rings that seal the joints of the solid-rocket boosters. Damaged O-rings, which need to stay pliable, contributed to the deadly explosion of the shuttle Challenger 10 years ago this month.
The warming devices were developed after the Challenger disaster, a NASA spokesman, George Diller, said.

"There's nothing exotic about these systems," Mr. Diller said. "But various parts of the shuttle perform best within a certain range, and these systems are designed to keep the temperatures just right."
The space agency said there was a 70 percent chance that Endeavour would blast off at 4:18 A.M. Thursday as planned. The biggest threat was clouds moving in from the Atlantic.

The six-member crew, which included a Japanese astronaut, is set for a nine-day flight. Their primary mission is to snare a four-ton Japanese satellite. Later, they are to drop a $10-million NASA satellite into orbit and reel it back two days later after gathering data for four experiments.
